title: JLR to pause work at its UK factories for one week in November
text:
Jaguar Land Rover will pause production at its British factories for a week in November to reduce disruption from a potential No Deal Brexit.

The luxury car maker will join fellow UK car makers BMW and Toyota, which have both planned similar shutdowns at Mini Plant Oxford and the Japanese firm's Burnaston site after the October 31 Brexit deadline.

JLR boss Ralf Speth said the firm had no other choice.

The Jaguar factory in Castle Bromwich, along with three other UK assembly plants, will be shutdown during November in preparation for post-Brexit supply-chain issues

Speaking at the opening of JLR's new engineering and development site in Gaydon, Warwickshire, Speth said: 'We cannot think about it, we just have to do it.

'I need 20 million parts a day and that means I have to make commitments to my suppliers.

'I have to have each and every part available, and I have to have it just in time.'

A day previously, No Deal Brexit minister Michael Gove said the industry had told him it was 'ready' for No Deal.

Car makers have been vocal opponents of a possible No Deal Brexit, which could wreak havoc with the supply chains.

Prime Minister Boris Johnson has vowed to take Britain out of the EU, with or without an exit deal, on October 31.

However, it remains unclear whether that will actually happen or if Brexit will be delayed, put back to a referendum or even cancelled.

The luxury car maker will join fellow UK car makers BMW and Toyota, which have both planned similar shutdowns after the October 31 Brexit deadline

Speth said that JLR would stop production at its four British factories during the first week of November.

This includes the engine facility in Wolverhampton, the Jaguar factory in Castle Bromwich and both Land Rover assembly plants in Halewood and Solihull.

He added that there would be a change to shift patterns at its Halewood factory near Liverpool leading to a cut in output due to the 'cyclical challenge' facing the car industry, which has prompted profit warnings and forecast cuts at a number of firms.

Japanese carmarker Toyota said in August it would not build cars at its British factory on 1 November while BMW will halt production at its Oxford plant on 31 October and 1 November.

Speth, who has led JLR for nearly a decade, has taken the company through a rapid expansion overseas but more recently the firm has posted losses due to a slowdown in China and a hit to diesel sales, particularly in Europe.

He made the announcement during JLR opening of an all-new state-of-the-art centre for creating electric and self-driving vehicles - the biggest of its kind in the UK.

Nearly 13,000 highly-skilled engineers and designers will work on the site, built on a former military airfield, as the struggling car manufacturer attempts to break away from its reliance on diesel engines to power its luxury four-wheeled drive cars.
